channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Republicans Denounce Inflation, but Few Economists Expect Their Plans to Help
item.description: Proposed tax and spending cuts by the G.O.P., which is making a push to take back Congress, are unlikely to bring down rapidly rising prices any time soon.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Republican candidates have offered few concrete plans to relieve price pressures should they win control of Congress.

item.title: Fetterman, Showing Stroke Effects, Battles Oz in Hostile Senate Debate
item.description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, a Democrat, tried to assure voters of his fitness to serve. Dr. Mehmet Oz, a former celebrity physician and Republican, attacked him as too radical for the job.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher

item.title: Climate Pledges Are Falling Short, and a Chaotic Future Looks More Like Reality
item.description: With an annual summit next month, the United Nations assessed progress on countries’ past emissions commitments. Severe disruption would be hard to avoid on the current trajectory.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A displaced Somali woman and her children near the carcasses of their livestock, killed by drought, in the country’s Gedo Region in May.

item.title: Stock Market Falls as Investors Fret About Tech Growth
item.description: Weak economic growth, rising inflation and a strong dollar are taking a toll on the tech giants that have an outsize impact on the stock market.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tech-heavy Nasdaq index is under pressure after a series of disappointing corporate earnings reports.

item.title: A Social Media Status Update
item.description: Top social media apps are struggling after a decade of dominance.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:description: Social media companies are having a troubling year.

item.title: Alphabet, Google’s Parent Company, Reports 27% Drop in Profit
item.description: Google’s parent company reported earnings that were below analysts’ expectations, bringing in $13.9 billion in profit on $69.1 billion in sales.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:credit: Laura Morton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of Google and its parent company Alphabet Inc. in Mountain View, Calif.

item.title: Shunned by the West, Russia and Myanmar Form a Partnership of Unequals
item.description: Myanmar gets resources and ammunition, while Russia gets a customer at a time when it is struggling for revenues. Both can use the other to undermine Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Myanmar fans and soldiers at the annual International Army Games in Russia in August. Myanmar’s engagement with Russia has grown this year.

item.title: Germany’s Allies Challenge Its Stances on Ukraine and Energy
item.description: The government has dismissed criticism of its refusal to provide modern tanks to Ukraine and its massive energy subsidy for its own citizens. But its friends are bridling.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, right; Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine, center; and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, at a conference in Berlin on Tuesday on the reconstruction of Ukraine. Germany has pushed back against the idea that it is isolating itself.

item.title: A Secret, Failed Oil Deal: How the U.S.-Saudi Relationship Ruptured
item.description: After Saudi leaders pushed to slash oil production despite a visit by President Biden, American officials have been left fuming that they were duped.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong and Adam Entous
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: President Biden arriving in Saudi Arabia in July. The administration thought it had secured a promise from the Saudis to keep oil flowing in a bid to stabilize prices.

item.title: NYU vs. Chicago Men’s Soccer: A Match Between Two Women Coaches
item.description: N.Y.U.’s Kim Wyant inspired Julianne Sitch to coach the University of Chicago. They will face off in a match in which both men’s teams are coached by women.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:description: “It’s amazing to play for her,” Nicholas Suter, one of N.Y.U.’s captains, said of Coach Kim Wyant. “It was one of the perks of coming here.”

item.title: How Elon Musk Became a Geopolitical Chaos Agent
item.description: The world’s richest man has inserted himself in some of the world’s most combustible conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Adam Satariano and Chang Che
item.media:description: Elon Musk, center, met the Chinese Premier Li Keqiang in Beijing in 2019. Mr. Musk has been criticized for statements regarding China’s interest in Taiwan.

item.title: Elon Musk Seems to Answer to No One. Except for a Judge in Delaware.
item.description: Kathaleen St. J. McCormick, the chief judge of Delaware’s Chancery Court, gave Mr. Musk until Friday to acquire Twitter. She is also the judge in at least one other case involving the billionaire.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch

item.title: New UK Leader Rishi Sunak Faces a Bruising First Prime Minister’s Questions
item.description: The opposition’s lines of attack, starting with Mr. Sunak’s choice of home secretary and his wife’s wealth, gave a glimpse of where it sees vulnerabilities in the governing Conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, leader of Britain’s main opposition party, said Rishi Sunak’s choice of home secretary was a “grubby deal” that showed him to be “weak.”

item.title: Rishi Sunak, New UK Prime Minister, Delays Economic Plan
item.description: Mr. Sunak’s government, seeking more time to make the “right decisions,” will deliver its first economic plan on Nov. 17 instead of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak leaving 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is the Future of Kanye West’s Music?
item.description: As corporate partners cut ties with the artist now known as Ye following weeks of antisemitic statements, many wonder if the recording catalog that was his bedrock will withstand the backlash.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli and Ben Sisario
item.media:description: While Ye once dominated the pop world with inescapable songs like “Jesus Walks,” “Gold Digger” and “Stronger,” he has not had a major hit in years.

item.title: Ina Garten Makes Risotto With a Longtime Fan
item.description: The designer Daniel Roseberry learned everything he knows about preparing a meal from the beloved cookbook author. For a new T series, the two finally met.
item.dc:creator: Mimi Vu

item.title: Putin Is Onto Us
item.description: When it comes to energy, the West wants five incompatible things at once.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Newsom vs. DeSantis Is Our Inevitable Culture War
item.description: Our future peace may depend on the outcome of the conflict between Gavin Newsom’s California and Ron DeSantis’s Florida.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.category: Divided We Fall: America's Secession Threat and How to Restore Our Nation (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photos by Justin Sullivan and Joe Raedle via Getty Images

item.title: What My Father’s Death Taught Me About Living
item.description: The most precious thing my dad gave me was an example of how to live a life devoid of cynicism and pessimism.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen

item.title: The Left-Right Divide Might Help Democrats Avoid a Total Wipeout
item.description: Even so, the party is feeling a distinct chill in the air.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall

item.title: The Trump Subpoena
item.description: The Jan. 6 committee has voted to subpoena former President Donald J. Trump. It’s a momentous move, but it’s not without precedent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Luke Vander Ploeg, John Ketchum, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jan. 6 committee’s decision last week has raised a question: Does former President Donald J. Trump have to comply with a congressional subpoena?

item.title: Some good news on energy
item.description: Renewable sources made up the vast majority of new generating capacity last year, a new report found. But the world’s energy transition still needs to speed up.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: The Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System in the Mojave Desert near Nipton, Calif.

item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Midnights’: Let’s Discuss
item.description: The blockbuster singer-songwriter’s 10th studio album finds her at a crossroads: Will she continue to reckon with her past, or forge another new path forward?

item.title: Soon, Jaywalking Will No Longer Be a Crime in California
item.description: Supporters of decriminalization, which takes effect Jan. 1, say the laws have disproportionately targeted people based on race and economic status.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Felix Uribe for The New York Times
item.media:description: When he was homeless for 12 years, Jason Sarris says the police targeted him with tickets for jaywalking and similar offenses that left him facing $5,000 in fines.

item.title: More Than 104,000 NYC Students Were Homeless Last Year
item.description: The number of students in temporary housing rose by about 3 percent, a daunting figure that does not include the thousands of migrant children who have recently entered city schools.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.category: Advocates for Children of New York
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hannah Bernard hands out work sheets during class at P.S. 446, Riverdale Avenue Community School, where 15 percent of the students were homeless in the 2020-21 school year.

item.title: Justice Dept. Seeks to Force Trump White House Lawyers to Testify in Jan. 6 Inquiry
item.description: The move is part of an effort by prosecutors to punch through the claims of privilege the former president is using to hamper the investigation of his push to overturn the election.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel, has appeared before a federal grand jury but declined to answer some questions.

item.title: Ashland Was Set to Be a Food Paradise. Then Came the Almeda Fire.
item.description: Two years ago, the Almeda fire tore through southern Oregon. Many people haven’t fully recovered, but farmers, chefs and others have rallied to sustain the area.
item.dc:creator: Brett Anderson
item.media:credit: Joe Kline for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Cook, the chef at Nama, moved from Texas to southern Oregon, where wildfires are a perennial problem.

item.title: Uterine Cancer: What to Know About Symptoms and Treatment
item.description: A new study raised alarms about chemical hair straighteners being linked to the disease, but doctors say there are telltale symptoms to watch for.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Is It Time to See a Sex Therapist?
item.description: Sex can be an important part of personal well-being. But sex therapists say the work they do remains misunderstood.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Black Women Can Interpret Those Scary Health Statistics
item.description: Doomsday headlines are nothing new. But over time they can damage your mental health if you’re not careful.
item.dc:creator: Jacquelynn Kerubo

item.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
item.description: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
item.dc:creator: Juno DeMelo
item.media:credit: Caleb Thal for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
